message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Sharing of misinformation is habitual, not just lazy or biased
Paper Abstract: Why do people share misinformation on social media? In this research ( N = 2,476), we show that the structure of online sharing built into social platforms is more important than individual deficits in critical reasoning and partisan bias—commonly cited drivers of misinformation. Due to the reward-based learning systems on social media, users form habits of sharing information that attracts others' attention. Once habits form, information sharing is automatically activated by cues on the platform without users considering response outcomes such as spreading misinformation. As a result of user habits, 30 to 40% of the false news shared in our research was due to the 15% most habitual news sharers. Suggesting that sharing of false news is part of a broader response pattern established by social media platforms, habitual users also shared information that challenged their own political beliefs. Finally, we show that sharing of false news is not an inevitable consequence of user habits: Social media sites could be restructured to build habits to share accurate information.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Habit formation"

Links: [{"title":"Habit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habit"},{"title":"Dynamic unobserved effects model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_unobserved_effects_model"},{"title":"Talk:Child vehicular heat stroke deaths - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Forgotten_baby_syndrome"},{"title":"Crystal habit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_habit"},{"title":"Botryoidal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Botryoidal"}]

Here are the search results for "Habit formation":

## Definition and Overview

Habit formation is the process by which a behavior, through regular repetition, becomes automatic or habitual.(no content)Habitual behavior often goes unnoticed by persons exhibiting it, because a person does not need to engage in self-analysis when undertaking routine tasks. Notably, a 2002 daily experience study by habit researcher Wendy Wood and her colleagues found that approximately 43% of daily behaviors are performed out of habit.

## Timeline of Formation

This process of habit formation can be slow. Research has provided specific timeframes: Lally et al. found the average time for participants to reach the asymptote of automaticity was 66 days with a range of 18–254 days.

## Key Components

There are four main components to habit formation: the context cue, craving, behavioral repetition, and the reward.(no content)The context cue can be a prior action, time of day, location, or anything that triggers the habitual behavior.

## Neural Basis

Old habits are hard to break and new habits are hard to form because the behavioural patterns that humans repeat become imprinted in neural pathways, but it is possible to form new habits through repetition.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Critical thinking"

Links: [{"title":"Critical Thinking (film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_Thinking_(film)"},{"title":"Critical systems thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_systems_thinking"},{"title":"Critical thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_thinking"},{"title":"Paris Institute for Critical Thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris_Institute_for_Critical_Thinking"},{"title":"Inquiry: Critical Thinking Across the Disciplines - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inquiry:_Critical_Thinking_Across_the_Disciplines"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wiki Ed/Wake Tech Community College/HUM 115 Critical Thinking (Fall 2017) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wiki_Ed/Wake_Tech_Community_College/HUM_115_Critical_Thinking_(Fall_2017)"},{"title":"Vertical thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_thinking"},{"title":"Logical reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_reasoning"},{"title":"Fake news - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news"},{"title":"Category:Critical thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Critical_thinking"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about critical thinking:

## Definition

Critical thinking is the process of analyzing available facts, evidence, observations, and arguments to make sound conclusions or informed choices.(no content)It involves recognizing underlying assumptions, providing justifications for ideas and actions, evaluating these justifications through comparisons with varying perspectives, and assessing their rationality and potential consequences.

## Key Characteristics

The goal of critical thinking is to form a judgment through the application of rational, skeptical, and unbiased analyses and evaluations.(no content)According to philosopher Richard W. Paul, critical thinking and analysis are competencies that can be learned or trained.

## Historical Background

In modern times, the use of the phrase critical thinking can be traced to John Dewey, who used the phrase reflective thinking, which depends on the knowledge base of an individual.(no content)In the classical period of Ancient Greece, the philosopher Plato indicated that the teachings of Socrates are the earliest records of what today is called critical thinking.

## Application

The application of critical thinking includes self-directed, self-disciplined, self-monitored, and self-corrective habits of the mind, as critical thinking is not a natural process; it must be induced, and ownership of the process must be taken for successful questioning and reasoning.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Social media"

Links: [{"title":"Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media"},{"title":"Social media marketing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_marketing"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"List of social platforms with at least 100 million active users - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_platforms_with_at_least_100_million_active_users"},{"title":"Timeline of social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_social_media"},{"title":"List of social networking services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_networking_services"},{"title":"Category:Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Social_media"},{"title":"Social media as a news source - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_as_a_news_source"},{"title":"The Social Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Network"},{"title":"Social web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_web"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of social media:

## Definition and Purpose

Social media are new media technologies that facilitate the creation, sharing and aggregation of content amongst virtual communities and networks.(no content)These interactive platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.

## Common Uses

Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn. They may be used to promote people, companies, products, and ideas. Social media can be used to consume, publish, or share news.

## Major Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.(no content)Other popular platforms that are sometimes referred to as social media services include YouTube, Letterboxd, QQ, Quora, Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal, LINE, Snapchat, Viber, Reddit, Discord, and TikTok.

## Current Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

## Differences from Traditional Media

Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

## Concerns

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media"},{"title":"Social media marketing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_marketing"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"List of social platforms with at least 100 million active users - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_platforms_with_at_least_100_million_active_users"},{"title":"Timeline of social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_social_media"},{"title":"List of social networking services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_networking_services"},{"title":"Category:Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Social_media"},{"title":"Social media as a news source - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_as_a_news_source"},{"title":"The Social Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Network"},{"title":"Social web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_web"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of social media:

## Definition and Purpose

Social media are new media technologies that facilitate the creation, sharing and aggregation of content amongst virtual communities and networks.(no content)These interactive platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.

## Common Uses

Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn. They may be used to promote people, companies, products, and ideas. Social media can be used to consume, publish, or share news.

## Major Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.(no content)Other popular platforms that are sometimes referred to as social media services include YouTube, Letterboxd, QQ, Quora, Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal, LINE, Snapchat, Viber, Reddit, Discord, and TikTok.

## Current Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

## Differences from Traditional Media

Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

## Concerns

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.

Web search results for query: "Fake news"

Links: [{"title":"Fake news - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news"},{"title":"Fake news website - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news_website"},{"title":"List of fake news websites - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fake_news_websites"},{"title":"Fake news in India - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news_in_India"},{"title":"Fake News Awards - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_News_Awards"},{"title":"After Truth: Disinformation and the Cost of Fake News - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/After_Truth:_Disinformation_and_the_Cost_of_Fake_News"},{"title":"List of fake news troll farms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fake_news_troll_farms"},{"title":"Fake news websites in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news_websites_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of satirical fake news websites - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_satirical_fake_news_websites"},{"title":"List of miscellaneous fake news websites - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_miscellaneous_fake_news_websites"}]

I've completed a web search for "Fake news" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here's what the search results reveal:

## Definition

Fake news is false or misleading information presented as news. More specifically, fake news is defined as stories purporting to be news that are intentionally and verifiably false and has the capacity to misinform and mislead readers.

## Types and Characteristics

In some definitions, fake news includes satirical articles misinterpreted as genuine, and articles that employ sensationalist or clickbait headlines that are not supported in the text.(no content)Fake news websites are websites on the Internet that deliberately publish fake news—hoaxes, propaganda, and disinformation purporting to be real news—often using social media to drive web traffic and amplify their effect.

## Spread and Impact

The prevalence of fake news has increased with the recent rise of social media, especially the Facebook News Feed, and this misinformation is gradually seeping into the mainstream media.(no content)Several factors have been implicated in the spread of fake news, such as political polarization, post-truth politics, motivated reasoning, confirmation bias, and social media algorithms.

## Global Concerns

Some media analysts have seen them as a threat to democracy.(no content)Examples of countries with political actors that have been confirmed or suspected to be involved with fake news website networks include Brazil, India, Iran, Italy, the People's Republic of China, the Philippines, Russia, Ukraine (Luhansk), and the United States.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Partisan bias"

Links: [{"title":"Political bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_bias"},{"title":"Partisan (politics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_(politics)"},{"title":"Nonpartisanship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonpartisanship"},{"title":"Media bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_bias"},{"title":"Criticism of Wikipedia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Criticism_of_Wikipedia"},{"title":"Wikipedia:No. Wikipedia is NOT biased - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No._Wikipedia_is_NOT_biased"},{"title":"NewsNation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewsNation"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about partisan bias:

## Definition

Partisan bias exists in the media when reporters serve and create the leaning of a particular political party. More broadly, political bias refers to the bias or manipulation of information to favor a particular political position, party, or candidate.

## How It Manifests

Story selection, framing, tone, and the frequency of criticism or support of specific parties or people are all examples of partisan bias.(no content)When journalists intentionally or unintentionally show material in a way that prioritizes one political ideology or party over another, they are engaging in bias and affecting the public's perception of political events and individuals.

## Evidence and Impact

Research has documented partisan bias in major news outlets. Networks such as ABC, CBS, and NBC were shown to have a slight liberal bias, however, their slant varied according to the political administration in power, whereas Fox News showed a strong conservative bias.(no content)According to a Gallup study, 62% of Americans think the media favors one political party, with Republicans majority stating that the media favors Democrats.

## Effects on Individuals

Partisanship causes survey respondents to answer political surveys differently, even if the survey asks a question with an objective answer. People with strong partisan beliefs are 12% more likely to give an incorrect answer that benefits their preferred party than an incorrect answer that benefits another party. This is due to the phenomenon of motivated reasoning, of which there are several types, including "cheerleading" and congenial inference.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Reward learning"

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reward system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_system"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Kate Wassum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kate_Wassum"},{"title":"Reward hacking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_hacking"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"State–action–reward–state–action - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-action-reward-state-action"},{"title":"Reinforcement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement"},{"title":"Brain stimulation reward - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brain_stimulation_reward"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"}]

Here are the search results for "Reward learning":

## Overview

The search results cover several interconnected aspects of reward learning:

### Machine Learning Context

In machine learning and optimal control, reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.

### Key Concepts

To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

### Specialized Approaches

Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences. It involves training a reward model to represent preferences, which can then be used to train other models through reinforcement learning.

### Biological Perspective

From a neuroscience angle, the reward system (the mesocorticolimbic circuit) is a group of neural structures responsible for incentive salience (i.e., "wanting"; desire or craving for a reward and motivation), associative learning (primarily positive reinforcement and classical conditioning), and positively-valenced emotions.

The search results reveal that reward learning is studied across multiple disciplines including computer science, neuroscience, and psychology, each providing different perspectives on how agents (artificial or biological) learn to make decisions that maximize beneficial outcomes.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reward system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_system"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Kate Wassum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kate_Wassum"},{"title":"Reward hacking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_hacking"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"State–action–reward–state–action - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-action-reward-state-action"},{"title":"Reinforcement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement"},{"title":"Brain stimulation reward - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brain_stimulation_reward"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"}]

Here are the search results for "Reward learning":

## Overview

The search results cover several interconnected aspects of reward learning:

### Machine Learning Context

In machine learning and optimal control, reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.

### Key Concepts

To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

### Specialized Approaches

Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences. It involves training a reward model to represent preferences, which can then be used to train other models through reinforcement learning.

### Biological Perspective

From a neuroscience angle, the reward system (the mesocorticolimbic circuit) is a group of neural structures responsible for incentive salience (i.e., "wanting"; desire or craving for a reward and motivation), associative learning (primarily positive reinforcement and classical conditioning), and positively-valenced emotions.

The search results reveal that reward learning is studied across multiple disciplines including computer science, neuroscience, and psychology, each providing different perspectives on how agents (artificial or biological) learn to make decisions that maximize beneficial outcomes.

Web search results for query: "Misinformation"

Links: [{"title":"Misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation by governments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_governments"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation"},{"title":"Misinformation in the Gaza war - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_in_the_Gaza_war"},{"title":"Vaccine misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine_misinformation"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation by China - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_China"},{"title":"5G misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5G_misinformation"},{"title":"Misinformation about violence by transgender people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_about_violence_by_transgender_people"},{"title":"Misinformation about the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_about_the_2024_Atlantic_hurricane_season"},{"title":"Seed oil misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seed_oil_misinformation"}]

Here are the search results for "Misinformation":

## Definition and Key Distinctions

Misinformation is incorrect or misleading information.(no content)Whereas misinformation can exist with or without specific malicious intent, disinformation is deliberately deceptive and intentionally propagated.(no content)Misinformation is typically spread unintentionally, mostly caused by a lack of knowledge, an error, or simply a misunderstanding, which contrasts with disinformation.

## Forms and Impact

Misinformation can include inaccurate, incomplete, misleading, or false information as well as selective or half-truths.(no content)Misinformation can influence people's beliefs about communities, politics, medicine, and more.(no content)Research shows that several factors, including cognitive biases, emotional responses, social dynamics, and media literacy levels, can influence susceptibility to misinformation.

## Spread Through Media

Social media platforms, such as Facebook, Instagram, X, etc., are designed in ways that enable information, including misinformation, to be posted and shared far more quickly than through other communication mediums.

## Global Significance

In January 2024, the World Economic Forum identified misinformation and disinformation, propagated by both internal and external interests, to "widen societal and political divides" as the most severe global risks in the short term.

## Historical Context

Misinformation campaigns have existed for hundreds of years.(no content)These early trends set the foundation for modern digital misinformation, which now spreads even more efficiently along internet networks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Sharing of misinformation is habitual, not just lazy or biased." Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Type:** Contribution (the paper proposes novel findings about habit formation in misinformation sharing)

**Triples Identified (7 total):**

1. **Misinformation** (task) - uses - The paper addresses the problem of why people share misinformation on social media
2. **Social media** (tool) - uses - The paper studies misinformation sharing and the reward-based structures of social platforms
3. **Habit** (concept) - **proposes** - The paper proposes that misinformation sharing is habitual behavior formed through reward systems
4. **Reinforcement learning** (concept) - uses - Explains how reward-based learning systems create sharing habits
5. **Political bias** (concept) - uses - Contrasts partisan bias with habit formation as an explanation for misinformation sharing
6. **Critical thinking** (concept) - uses - Argues that platform structure matters more than individual deficits in critical reasoning
7. **Fake news** (task) - uses - Studies the sharing patterns of false news and habitual mechanisms

**Validation:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

The analysis correctly identified that this is a contribution paper (it proposes new insights about habit-based misinformation sharing) with at least one "proposes" relation (the Habit triple) and multiple "uses" relations (7 total triples), meeting all validation requirements.

Sources:
- [Misinformation - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation)
- [Social media - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media)
- [Habit - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habit)
- [Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning)
- [Political bias - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_bias)
- [Critical thinking - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_thinking)
- [Fake news - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news)
